Map_Sources: no sea factible realizar la sustracción del área protegida
Notes: se procederá a manifestarlo mediante acto administrativo motivado rechazando la solicitud y procediendo a su archivo. La autoridad encargada de adelantar el trámite de sustracción
Date_Add: para resolver la solicitud deberá tener en cuenta al menos los siguientes criterios
Last_Update: los cuales deberán ser analizados de forma integral y complementaria: a) Representatividad ecológica: Que la zona a sustraer no incluya elementos de biodiversidad (paisajes
isLatestVe: no representados o insuficientemente representados en el sistema nacional de áreas protegidas
Data_Status: de acuerdo a las metas de conservación definidas. b) Integridad ecológica: Que la zona a sustraer no permita que se mantenga la integridad ecológica del área protegida o no garantice la dinámica natural de cambio de los atributos que caracterizan su biodiversidad. c) Irremplazabilidad: Que la zona a sustraer no considere muestras únicas o
Peer_Reviewed: ~ poco comunes y remanentes de tipos de ecosistemas. d) Representatividad de especies: Que la zona a sustraer no incluya el hábitat de especies consideradas en alguna categoría global
Study_Link: nacional o regional de amenaza
Off_Type: conforme el ámbito de gestión de la categoría. e) Significado cultural: Que la zona a sustraer no incluya espacios naturales que contribuyan al mantenimiento de zonas estratégicas de conservación cultural
Off_Area: como un proceso activo para la pervivencia de los grupos étnicos reconocidos como culturas diferenciadas en el país.

primarynam: Cuenca del Río Cravo Sur Forest Reserve Protectress National
allnames: Reserva Forestal Protectora Nacional Cuenca del Río Cravo Sur, Cuenca del Río Cravo Sur Forest Reserve Protectress National
Supporting:
Decree 2372 of 2010 issued by the Ministry of Environment, Housing and Territorial Development whose validity lasts from 2010 to 2017, affected the categories of Protective Forest Reserves, integrated management districts, soil conservation districts and recreation protected areas, and constitutes a systemic downgrading event for national protective reserves and integrated management districts. This Decree regulates the substraction of protected areas (applies to 57 units). 

\Articulo 30. SUSTRACCiÓN DE ÁREAS PROTEGIDAS. La conservación y mejoramiento del ambiente es de utilidad pública e interés social. Cuando por otras razones de utilidad pública e interés social se proyecten desarrollar usos y actividades no permitidas al interior de un área protegida
Sources: atendiendo al régimen legal de la categoría de manejo
Map_Details: el interesado en el proyecto deberá solicitar previamente la sustracción del área de interés ante la autoridad que la declaró. En el evento que conforme a las normas que regulan cada área protegida
Map_Sources: no sea factible realizar la sustracción del área protegida
Notes: se procederá a manifestarlo mediante acto administrativo motivado rechazando la solicitud y procediendo a su archivo. La autoridad encargada de adelantar el trámite de sustracción
Date_Add: para resolver la solicitud deberá tener en cuenta al menos los siguientes criterios
Last_Update: los cuales deberán ser analizados de forma integral y complementaria: a) Representatividad ecológica: Que la zona a sustraer no incluya elementos de biodiversidad (paisajes
isLatestVe: no representados o insuficientemente representados en el sistema nacional de áreas protegidas
Data_Status: de acuerdo a las metas de conservación definidas. b) Integridad ecológica: Que la zona a sustraer no permita que se mantenga la integridad ecológica del área protegida o no garantice la dinámica natural de cambio de los atributos que caracterizan su biodiversidad. c) Irremplazabilidad: Que la zona a sustraer no considere muestras únicas o
Peer_Reviewed: ~ poco comunes y remanentes de tipos de ecosistemas. d) Representatividad de especies: Que la zona a sustraer no incluya el hábitat de especies consideradas en alguna categoría global
Study_Link: nacional o regional de amenaza
Off_Type: conforme el ámbito de gestión de la categoría. e) Significado cultural: Que la zona a sustraer no incluya espacios naturales que contribuyan al mantenimiento de zonas estratégicas de conservación cultural
Off_Area: como un proceso activo para la pervivencia de los grupos étnicos reconocidos como culturas diferenciadas en el país.

Decree 2372 of 2010 issued by the Ministry of Environment, Housing and Territorial Development whose validity lasts from 2010 to 2017, affected the categories of Protective Forest Reserves, integrated management districts, soil conservation districts and recreation protected areas, and constitutes a systemic downgrading event for national protective reserves and integrated management districts. This Decree regulates the substraction of protected areas (applies to 57 units).

primarynam: De Urrao Forest Reserve Protectress National
allnames: Reserva Forestal Protectora Nacional De Urrao, De Urrao Forest Reserve Protectress National
Supporting:
Law 99 of 1993, article 49 of 1974 (and related Decree 1220 of 2005) was issued by the Congress of Colombia. Its validity lasted from 1974 to 2010. It affected the category of National Protective Forest Reserves (Reservas Forestales Protectoras Nacionales) and constituted an enacted systemic downgrading event. It affected the 57 National Protective Forest Reserves that were established at the time. 

This law states that it is possible within Forest Reserves to carry out economic activities, such as the construction of infrastructure works, roads, reservoirs, dams or buildings, provided it is proven that they do not undermine the conservation of the renewable resources of the area. All economic activities that do not require an environmental license can be developed within the forest reserve areas, as long as no one of the causes that make the removal necessary, and implementing the necessary means to protect the reserve.
Sources: http://www.humboldt.org.co/images/documentos/pdf/Normativo/1993-12-22-ley-99-crea-el-sina-y-mma.pdf
Study_Link: R.E. Golden Kroner et al., The uncertain future of protected lands and waters. Science. 31, 364 (6443), 881-886 (2019). DOI: 10.1126/science.aau5525.
Rev_Details: The law was valid betwen 1993 and 2010
Rev_Source: Law 685 of 2001, article 34 of the mining code. Sentence C-649 of 1997 issued by the Constitutional Court whose validity lasts from 2001 to 2010, affecting the category of the National System of Natural Parks and presents a systemic downsizing event

allnames: Parque Nacional Natural Los Katíos, Los Katíos Natural National Park

This was precluded by  Sentence C-649 of 1997 issued by the Constitutional Court.  This enabled portions of reserves to be downsized (substracted/\substraer\" for mining activities) and affected 102 protected areas.

primarynam: La Planada Forest Reserve Protectress National
allnames: Reserva Forestal Protectora Nacional La Planada, La Planada Forest Reserve Protectress National
Supporting:
Law 99 of 1993, article 49 of 1974 (and related Decree 1220 of 2005) was issued by the Congress of Colombia. Its validity lasted from 1974 to 2010. It affected the category of National Protective Forest Reserves (Reservas Forestales Protectoras Nacionales) and constituted an enacted systemic downgrading event. It affected the 57 National Protective Forest Reserves that were established at the time. 

This law states that it is possible within Forest Reserves to carry out economic activities, such as the construction of infrastructure works, roads, reservoirs, dams or buildings, provided it is proven that they do not undermine the conservation of the renewable resources of the area. All economic activities that do not require an environmental license can be developed within the forest reserve areas, as long as no one of the causes that make the removal necessary, and implementing the necessary means to protect the reserve.
Sources: http://www.humboldt.org.co/images/documentos/pdf/Normativo/1993-12-22-ley-99-crea-el-sina-y-mma.pdf

primarynam: Cuenca Alta del Río Cali Forest Reserve Protectress National
allnames: Reserva Forestal Protectora Nacional Cuenca Alta del Río Cali, Cuenca Alta del Río Cali Forest Reserve Protectress National
Supporting:
Resolución 126 de 1998 by Ministry of Environment. Reduces two forest reserves: Reserva Forestal del Río Cali y del Río Melendez. The Resolution discusses the requirement for an offset – a new forest reserve to be established that is no smaller than 970.69 hectares, before December 31, 1998. However, it does not appear that any new protected areas were established in Colombia in 1998 (or 1999 – 2004). 

“Por medio de la cual se hace unas sustracciones de las áreas de Reserva Forestal del Río Cali y del Río Melendez, creadas mediante Resoluciones Números 9 de 1938, 5 de 1943 y 7 de 1941 respectivamente, proferidas por el Ministerio de Economía Nacional

Decree 2372 of 2010 issued by the Ministry of Environment, Housing and Territorial Development whose validity lasts from 2010 to 2017, affected the categories of Protective Forest Reserves, integrated management districts, soil conservation districts and recreation protected areas, and constitutes a systemic downgrading event for national protective reserves and integrated management districts. This Decree regulates the substraction of protected areas (applies to 57 units). 

\Articulo 30. SUSTRACCiÓN DE ÁREAS PROTEGIDAS. La conservación y mejoramiento del ambiente es de utilidad pública e interés social. Cuando por otras razones de utilidad pública e interés social se proyecten desarrollar usos y actividades no permitidas al interior de un área protegida

Peer_Reviewed: ~ poco comunes y remanentes de tipos de ecosistemas. d) Representatividad de especies: Que la zona a sustraer no incluya el hábitat de especies consideradas en alguna categoría global

primarynam: Páramo Grande Forest Reserve Protectress National
allnames: Reserva Forestal Protectora Nacional Páramo Grande, Páramo Grande Forest Reserve Protectress National
Supporting:
Law 99 of 1993, article 49 of 1974 (and related Decree 1220 of 2005) was issued by the Congress of Colombia. Its validity lasted from 1974 to 2010. It affected the category of National Protective Forest Reserves (Reservas Forestales Protectoras Nacionales) and constituted an enacted systemic downgrading event. It affected the 57 National Protective Forest Reserves that were established at the time. 

This law states that it is possible within Forest Reserves to carry out economic activities, such as the construction of infrastructure works, roads, reservoirs, dams or buildings, provided it is proven that they do not undermine the conservation of the renewable resources of the area. All economic activities that do not require an environmental license can be developed within the forest reserve areas, as long as no one of the causes that make the removal necessary, and implementing the necessary means to protect the reserve.
Sources: http://www.humboldt.org.co/images/documentos/pdf/Normativo/1993-12-22-ley-99-crea-el-sina-y-mma.pdf
Study_Link: R.E. Golden Kroner et al., The uncertain future of protected lands and waters. Science. 31, 364 (6443), 881-886 (2019). DOI: 10.1126/science.aau5525.
Rev_Details: The law was valid betwen 1993 and 2010
Rev_Source: Law 685 of 2001, article 34 of the mining code. Sentence C-649 of 1997 issued by the Constitutional Court whose validity lasts from 2001 to 2010, affecting the category of the National System of Natural Parks and presents a systemic downsizing event

primarynam: Cuenca del Río Tame Forest Reserve Protectress National
allnames: Reserva Forestal Protectora Nacional Cuenca del Río Tame, Cuenca del Río Tame Forest Reserve Protectress National
Supporting:
Law 99 of 1993, article 49 of 1974 (and related Decree 1220 of 2005) was issued by the Congress of Colombia. Its validity lasted from 1974 to 2010. It affected the category of National Protective Forest Reserves (Reservas Forestales Protectoras Nacionales) and constituted an enacted systemic downgrading event. It affected the 57 National Protective Forest Reserves that were established at the time. 

This law states that it is possible within Forest Reserves to carry out economic activities, such as the construction of infrastructure works, roads, reservoirs, dams or buildings, provided it is proven that they do not undermine the conservation of the renewable resources of the area. All economic activities that do not require an environmental license can be developed within the forest reserve areas, as long as no one of the causes that make the removal necessary, and implementing the necessary means to protect the reserve.
Sources: http://www.humboldt.org.co/images/documentos/pdf/Normativo/1993-12-22-ley-99-crea-el-sina-y-mma.pdf

This Decree regulates the substraction of protected areas (applies to 57 units). 

\Articulo 30. SUSTRACCiÓN DE ÁREAS PROTEGIDAS. La conservación y mejoramiento del ambiente es de utilidad pública e interés social. Cuando por otras razones de utilidad pública e interés social se proyecten desarrollar usos y actividades no permitidas al interior de un área protegida

Peer_Reviewed: ~ poco comunes y remanentes de tipos de ecosistemas. d) Representatividad de especies: Que la zona a sustraer no incluya el hábitat de especies consideradas en alguna categoría global

Supporting:
Decree 2372 of 2010 issued by the Ministry of Environment, Housing and Territorial Development whose validity lasts from 2010 to 2017, affected the categories of Protective Forest Reserves, integrated management districts, soil conservation districts and recreation protected areas, and constitutes a systemic downgrading event for national protective reserves and integrated management districts. This Decree regulates the substraction of protected areas (applies to 57 units). 

\Articulo 30. SUSTRACCiÓN DE ÁREAS PROTEGIDAS. La conservación y mejoramiento del ambiente es de utilidad pública e interés social. Cuando por otras razones de utilidad pública e interés social se proyecten desarrollar usos y actividades no permitidas al interior de un área protegida

primarynam: Río San Francisco Forest Reserve Protectress National
allnames: Reserva Forestal Protectora Nacional Río San Francisco, Río San Francisco Forest Reserve Protectress National
Supporting:
Law 99 of 1993, article 49 of 1974 (and related Decree 1220 of 2005) was issued by the Congress of Colombia. Its validity lasted from 1974 to 2010. It affected the category of National Protective Forest Reserves (Reservas Forestales Protectoras Nacionales) and constituted an enacted systemic downgrading event. It affected the 57 National Protective Forest Reserves that were established at the time. 

This law states that it is possible within Forest Reserves to carry out economic activities, such as the construction of infrastructure works, roads, reservoirs, dams or buildings, provided it is proven that they do not undermine the conservation of the renewable resources of the area. All economic activities that do not require an environmental license can be developed within the forest reserve areas, as long as no one of the causes that make the removal necessary, and implementing the necessary means to protect the reserve.
Sources: http://www.humboldt.org.co/images/documentos/pdf/Normativo/1993-12-22-ley-99-crea-el-sina-y-mma.pdf
Study_Link: R.E. Golden Kroner et al., The uncertain future of protected lands and waters. Science. 31, 364 (6443), 881-886 (2019). DOI: 10.1126/science.aau5525.

primarynam: Quebrada Tenería Forest Reserve Protectress National
allnames: Reserva Forestal Protectora Nacional Quebrada Tenería, Quebrada Tenería Forest Reserve Protectress National
Supporting:
Law 99 of 1993, article 49 of 1974 (and related Decree 1220 of 2005) was issued by the Congress of Colombia. Its validity lasted from 1974 to 2010. It affected the category of National Protective Forest Reserves (Reservas Forestales Protectoras Nacionales) and constituted an enacted systemic downgrading event. It affected the 57 National Protective Forest Reserves that were established at the time. 

This law states that it is possible within Forest Reserves to carry out economic activities, such as the construction of infrastructure works, roads, reservoirs, dams or buildings, provided it is proven that they do not undermine the conservation of the renewable resources of the area. All economic activities that do not require an environmental license can be developed within the forest reserve areas, as long as no one of the causes that make the removal necessary, and implementing the necessary means to protect the reserve.
Sources: http://www.humboldt.org.co/images/documentos/pdf/Normativo/1993-12-22-ley-99-crea-el-sina-y-mma.pdf
Study_Link: R.E. Golden Kroner et al., The uncertain future of protected lands and waters. Science. 31, 364 (6443), 881-886 (2019). DOI: 10.1126/science.aau5525.
Rev_Details: The law was valid betwen 1993 and 2010
Rev_Source: Law 685 of 2001, article 34 of the mining code. Sentence C-649 of 1997 issued by the Constitutional Court whose validity lasts from 2001 to 2010, affecting the category of the National System of Natural Parks and presents a systemic downsizing event

allnames: Los Haitises National Park
Supporting: Los Haitises National Park is the protected area which has suffered most changes in its definition. PADDDed area here was calculated from its legal definition in 1997 Presidential Decree 94-97)vs. its 2009 area (Presidential Decree no.571 of 2009). The 2009 polygon reduced part of the Park's \core\" area of 1997. It also merged part of the 1997 Park's core and buffer areas for the new park definition
Sources: but left no buffer area defined. Part of the lost buffer area to the north (56km2) is protected by a new area (first created in 2004 and ratified in 2009) called \"Manglares del Bajo Yuna National Park\"."
Map_Details:
Perdomo L, Arias Y, León YM, Wege D. 2010. Parque Nacional Los Haitises. Pp 66-69 in: Areas Importantes para la conservación de Aves de la República Dominicana. Grupo Jaragua, Santo Domingo. Available online at: http://www.grupojaragua.org.do/documents/AICAS/DR-IBAS_2010_DO018_Los_Haitises.pdf (access date: 18 Jan 2013)

Decreto 571-09 que crea varios parques nacionales, monumentos naturales, reservas biológicas, reservas científicas, santuarios marinos, refugios de vida silvestre, Área Nacional de Recreo Boca de Nigua y el Monumento Nacional Salto de Jimenoa. Establece una zona de amortiguamiento o de uso sostenible de 300 metros alrededor de todas las unidades de conservación que ostentan las categorías genéricas de la Unión Mundial para la Naturaleza; dispone la realización de un inventario nacional de varios humedales, y crea una franja de protección de 250 metros alrededor del vaso de todas las presas del país. Available online at: http://www.accionverde.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/10/Texto-Integro-del-Decreto-Dec.-No.-571-09-que-crea-32-Nuevas-Areas-PARTE-I-TEXTO.pdf (access date 18 Jan 2013)
Study_Link: Y
Off_Type: R.E. Golden Kroner et al., The uncertain future of protected lands and waters. Science. 31, 364 (6443), 881-886 (2019). DOI: 10.1126/science.aau5525.

allnames: Yasuni National Park; Yasuni Biosphere Reserve; Parque Nacional Yasuni; Parque Nacional y Reserva de Biosfera Yasuni
Supporting:
The Yasuni ITT initiative was cancelled in 2013, permitting hydrocarbon development in blocks 31 and 43, where it had previously been prohibited. 

\In June 2007
Sources: “a big idea from a small country” was unveiled to the world by the then-recently elected President of Ecuador
Map_Sources: in the form of the Yasuni-ITT Initiative. The Initiative was the proposal by the government of Ecuador to refrain indefinitely from exploiting the oil reserves of the Ishpingo-Tambococha-Tiputini (ITT) oil field
Date_Add: and located within Yasuni National Park
Last_Update: in exchange for financial contributions worth 50% of the value of the reserves from the international community. Yasuni National Park
isLatestVe: is Ecuador’s largest national park after the Galapagos Islands
Data_Status: and is “singularly one of the most important sites for biodiversity anywhere on the planet”. Home to 173 mammal species
Peer_Reviewed: over 40 percent of Ecuador’s rich and diverse bird population
Study_Link: one square mile of Yasuni has as many trees and shrubs species as in the whole of North America. It is also home to the Huoarani indigenous tribe as well as the two uncontacted groups
Off_Details: environmentalists and indigenous rights activists alike hailed the largely oil-dependent country’s unprecedented initiative as a major victory and step in the right direction. Nevertheless
Rev_Type: six years after it had been launched
Rev_Area: President Correa announced that his government had come to the decision to abandon the initiative and liquidate the Yasuni-ITT trust fund
Rev_Details: and would go ahead with drilling for oil in Block ITT. The main reason given for the decision was that only $13 million – a small fraction of the initially pledged funds of over $100 million – had actually been donated
Rev_Source: and that “the world had failed them”.  The government subsequently signed permits for drilling in May 2014
Legal_Type: with the intention that oil drilling could begin as soon as 2016.\" (Keyman 2015)

PADDD_ID: The 2008 ITT initiative was repealed in 2013 by Decreto Ejecutivo No 74 of August 15
Country: 03-09-2013). It declared that 1% of Yasuni National Park would be open to oil drilling. Later in 2013

WDPAID: to state that the area of drilling would be 0.1% of Yasuni National Park.

Oil and gas activity was declared off-limits in 2007 with the Yasuni ITT-initiative. However, this initiative was cancelled in 2013.
 \In June 2007
IUCN_post: “a big idea from a small country” was unveiled to the world by the then-recently elected President of Ecuador
YR_Reverse: in the form of the Yasuni-ITT Initiative. The Initiative was the proposal by the government of Ecuador to refrain indefinitely from exploiting the oil reserves of the Ishpingo-Tambococha-Tiputini (ITT) oil field
Systemic: and located within Yasuni National Park
Sys_Code: in exchange for financial contributions worth 50% of the value of the reserves from the international community. Yasuni National Park
Supporting: a UNESCO World Biosphere Reserve
Sources: is Ecuador’s largest national park after the Galapagos Islands
Map_Details: and is “singularly one of the most important sites for biodiversity anywhere on the planet”. Home to 173 mammal species
Map_Sources: over 40 percent of Ecuador’s rich and diverse bird population
Notes: one square mile of Yasuni has as many trees and shrubs species as in the whole of North America. It is also home to the Huoarani indigenous tribe as well as the two uncontacted groups
AddedBy: environmentalists and indigenous rights activists alike hailed the largely oil-dependent country’s unprecedented initiative as a major victory and step in the right direction. Nevertheless
Data_Status: six years after it had been launched
Peer_Reviewed: President Correa announced that his government had come to the decision to abandon the initiative and liquidate the Yasuni-ITT trust fund
Study_Link: and would go ahead with drilling for oil in Block ITT. The main reason given for the decision was that only $13 million – a small fraction of the initially pledged funds of over $100 million – had actually been donated
Off_Type: and that “the world had failed them”.  The government subsequently signed permits for drilling in May 2014
Off_Area: with the intention that oil drilling could begin as soon as 2016.\" (Keyman 2015)"

Authorizes the construction of seismic lines, heliports, base camps, and other infrastructure related to hydrocarbon development in Block 31

\Autorizra a la Compañia PEREZ COMPANC S.A. dentro de la ejecucion del Contrato de Participacion suscrito con el Estado Ecuatoriano
Sources: la realizacion de actividades de Prospeccion Sismica en el Bloque 31 localizado en la zona nor-oriental del Parque Nacional Yasuni al oeste de la comunidad de Garzacocha
Map_Details: de acuerdo y observando las siguientes condiciones tecnicas: a) La ejecucion de las actividades de prospeccion sismica se realizaran en un periodo aproximado de 6 meses
Map_Sources: cumpliendo estrictamente con las regulaciones dispuestas en el Reglamento Ambiental 2982 y otras normas internacionales aplicables a las operaciones sismicas en Bosque Humedo Tropical
Notes: lo dispuesto en el Plan de Manejo Ambiental presentado por la compania PEREZ COMPANC SA para las operaciones de sismica en el Bloque 31 y las siguientes disposiciones tecnicas: a. 1. El ancho de la linea de trocha se mandendra en 1.20 m. a2. Se construiran 105 helipuertos en total y sus dimensiones maximas seran de 30 m por 30 m localizados en los cruces de las lineas del mallado sismico y no afectaran zonas de humedales ni zonas cologicamente sensibles como saladeros y/o yacimientos arquelogicos.  a3. Como puntos de apoyo logistico se construiran zonas de descarga (DZs) a una distancia aproximada de 600 m y sus dimensiones no excederan los 36 m2. En casa de topografia irregular y por razones de seguridad debidamente justificados se ampliara a 64 m2.  a4. Los puntos de disparo se localizaran cada cien metros
Date_Add: la carga depositada no sera mayo a 1 kg y estara a una profundidad no menor de 25 m. El diametro de estos puntos de disparo sera de maximo 2.5 pulgadas. a.5 La distancia minima la que se localizara una linea y/o punto de disparo de un saladero sera de 50 m para evitar su afectacion. a.6. Para evitar mayor afectacion a la zona del bloque se construira el Campamento Base en la zona de Llanchama en la orilla sur del Rio Tiputini en un area previamente intervenida con una supervicie no mayor a las 1.5 has. El campamento se asentara sobre bases de madera excepto en el case de las oficinas de operacion que seran construidas con madera. La madera que se utilice provendra de fuera del area protegida y debera contar con la guia de movilizacion respectiva. a7. El campamento sub-base se construira en la zona de Huaorani-Ono localizada a 4 horas de Garzacocha rio arriba por el Yasuni. Tendra una exxtension no mayor de 0.5 ha y su base sera construida de madera utilizado la madera desbrozada del area mencionada para el efecto. Todas las estructuras restantes incluyendo la madera seran removidas en la fase de abandono y la madera sera entregada a la comunidad de Garzacocha. a8. Para evitar la compactacion y erosion del suelo en las zonas de aterrizaje del helicoptero en los helipuertos asi como las zonas de los compamentos base y sub-base y en los compamentos volantes
Last_Update: se removera la capa de suelo fertil y se la manderdra aparte y cubierta mientras dure la operacion. En la fase de abandono esta capa sera restituida a sus lugares originales para que la revegetacion sea mas rapida y efectiva. / Authorizes the company PEREZ COMPANC S.A. within the execution of the Participation Contract signed with the Ecuadorian State
AddedBy: the carrying out of Seismic Survey activities in Block 31 located in the north-eastern zone of the Yasuni National Park to the west of the community of Garzacocha
isLatestVe: in agreement and observing the following technical conditions: a) The execution of seismic survey activities will be carried out in a period of approximately 6 months

Study_Link: such as salting grounds and / or archaeological sites. a3. As logistic support points

\Art. 1.- Aprobar el Estudio de Impacto Ambiental y Plan de Manejo Ambiental del proyecto \"Canal de Riego Tabacundo\" correspondiente a la fase de intervención al interior de la reserva ecológica Cayambe - Coca y consecuentemente
Sources: otorgar la licencia ambiental respectiva para el inicio de la actividad propuesta en el proyecto

allnames: Reserva Ecologica Los Ilinizas
Supporting:
Los Ilinizas was established in 1996 by RESOLUCION NO. 066 DEL 11/12/1996 (REGISTRO OFICIAL NO. 92 DEL 19/12/1996) with a size of 1499 km2. The SNAP database says that it has not been modified, but the SNAP files (e.g. comparing 2007 to 2008 and beyond) the boundary clearly shows that a piece was removed from the PA. The accompanying legal document, nor the information about the current extent, not available. The boundary change is confirmed using: 
1. Management plan (MAE and DNB 2008), which shows the boundary of the park before the downsize. This boundary is also replicated in scanned maps from 2004 (MAE and CIAM) and 2009 (ECOLAP and MAE). 
2. SNAP databases of 2007 and 2008, which clearly show a large difference between the boundaries and indicate that a downsize occurred.
3. MAE park guide (MAE 2014), showing the new boundary of Ilinizas and showing that the park was downsized.

None of these documents include the current size of the PA. Protected Planet and SNAP (same database) report the current area as 1342.3324953 km2, which is smaller than the enabling legislation reports the area. The enabling legislation also established Los Ilinizas to have three sections; after the downsize, it now has four, as the downsize split the largest section into two polygons.   

An overlay with the Bosques y Vegetacion Protectores (BVPs) shows that the private preserve called Zarapullo overlaps with the area of the downsize. BVP Zarapullo (sometimes listed as Sarapullo) was established by: REGISTRO OFICIAL NO. 489 DEL 30 DE JULIO DE 1986 CON RESOLUCION MINISTERIAL NO.234 DEL 26 DE JUNIO DE 1986. The BVP database says that this information is being verified, however.

The area affected by the downsize was calculated with the following rationale:
The original area as listed in the legislation (1499 km2) does not match the area in GIS. The boundary change legal document could not be located to confirm the new area. The only piece of information available to measure the size is the shapefiles. The size of Los Ilinizas was measured before and after the boundary change - sizes were measured as 1547 km2 and 1342 km2 respectively. The difference of these is 205 km2. Values as measured in GIS were cross multiplied (1547 km2 / 205 km2 for the boundary before and the downsize, respectively) with the original size as provided in the enabling legislation (1499 km2). The result - the size of the downsize that is estimated to be listed in the boundary change legal document - is 198.64 km. This value is listed for the downsize and the SizePost is the difference between the original area (1499 km2) and this value.
Sources:
1. MAE (Ministerio del Ambiente) Ecuador. 2017.  Areas Naturales Protegidas. Downloaded from http://mapainteractivo.ambiente.gob.ec/portal/ Accessed 10/27/2017
2. MAE (Ministerio del Ambiente) Ecuador. 2014. Reserva Ecologica Los Ilinizas: Guia Parque. http://areasprotegidas.ambiente.gob.ec/sites/default/files/GUIA_PARQUES_30-2014_0.pdf
3. MAE (Ministerio del Ambiente) and DNB (Direcion Nacional de Biodiversidad). 2008. Plan de Manejo: Reserva Ecologica Ilinizas (REI). Volumen V. http://suia.ambiente.gob.ec/documents/10179/242256/30+PLAN+DE+MANEJO+ILINIZAS.pdf/a4b31f30-95a5-43e9-8875-c51258f08b4d 
4. MAE (Ministerio del Ambiente) and CIAM (Centro de Informacion Ambiental). 2004. Sistema Nacional de Areas Naturales Protegidas del Ecuador (SNAP): Areas Protegidas Actuales. Scanned June 2017. file:///E:/Dropbox/Rachel/GMU/Dissertation/Ecuador/Ecuador%20Scanned%20Maps%20and%20Documents/Batch%201/IMAG0277%20-%20whole%20system.PDF
5. ECOLAP (Instituo del Ecologia Aplicada) and MAE (Ministero del Ambiente del Ecuador). 2007. Guia del Patrimonio del Areas Naturales Protegidas del Ecuador. ECOFUND, FAN, DarwinNet, IGM. Quito, Ecuador. Scanned June 2017: E:\Dropbox\Rachel\GMU\Dissertation\Ecuador\Ecuador Scanned Maps and Documents\Batch 2\IMAG0099
6. MAE (Ministerio del Ambiente) 2007. Areas Naturales Protegidas shapefile. Shared by MAE.
Map_Details: The polygon map of the downsize of Ilinizas was created by taking the difference between the 2007 and 2008 SNAP shapefiles, provided by MAE. The 2007 shapefile did not line up with the 2008 shapefile, so I used the Snapping tool (edge) to line it up before erasing. I then cleaned up the remaining edges from the erase product in GIS.

allnames: Yasuni National Park; Yasuni Biosphere Reserve; Parque Nacional Yasuni; Parque Nacional y Reserva de Biosfera Yasuni
Supporting:
The boundary of Yasuni National Park was changed in 1990 to remove portions and add others. The legal document states that the boundary change was justified to remove indigenous (Waorani) ancestral lands from the protected area and respect traditional rights. In addition, secondary sources and key informant interviews reveal that the boundary change was a gateway to the first hydrocarbon development in the region.

allnames: Sangay National Park; Parque Nacional Sangay
Supporting:
Sangay National Park was downsized to accommodate previously-established private lands in the region, which had been incorporated into the protected area when it was expanded in 1992. No proximate cause is provided in the legal documents. Key informant interviews revealed that the expansion of the park in 1992 was done without consideration of private lands held in the region. In addition, a road was proposed to be built in the region where the downsize occurred. Therefore, the multiple proximate causes here include land claims and infrastructure (road construction).

primarynam: Abattis and Mountain Cottica Classified Site
allnames: Site Classé Abattis et Montagne Cottica
Supporting:
Downsize of the PA from 32000 to 16000 ha. At the same time as the downsize, the site was upgraded. The original protected area (established in 2006 site 'inscrit' (32000 ha) was changed in 2011 to site 'classé' (16000ha). 'Classé' is a stronger protection than 'inscrit', so this constitutes a regulatory offset. 

Ministerial Decree (2005) “La  ministre  de  l’écologie  et  du  développement  durable,Vu  le  code  de  l'environnement,  notamment  ses  articles  L.  341-1,  R.  341-1  à  R  341-3  et  R.  341-8,Vu  les  délibérations  du  conseil  municipal  de  Papaïchton  en  date  du  31  août  2002  et  28  mai  2004,Vu l'avisé mis parla commission départementale dessites, perspectives et paysages de la Guyane en date du 25 juillet 2002 et 8 juin 2005, Considérant que la préservation du site des Abattis et de la Montagne Kotika présente, en raison de ses caractères pittoresque, légendaire  et  historique,  un  intérêt  général  au  sens  de  l'article  L.  341-1  du  code  de  l'environnement  arrete ARRÊTE: Article 1er: Est inscrit parmi les sites du département de la Guyane, l’ensemble formé parles Abattis et la Montagne Kotikasur le territoire de la commune de Papaïchton,  d’unesuperficie d’environ  32  000  hectares” / “The Minister of Ecology and Sustainable Development, Having regard to the Environment Code, in particular Articles L. 341-1, R. 341-1 to R. 341-3 and R. 341-8, Having regard to the deliberations of the Council Municipal Council of Papaïchton dated August 31, 2002 and May 28, 2004, Considering the advised by the departmental commission dessdes, perspectives and landscapes of Guyana dated July 25, 2002 and June 8, 2005, Whereas the preservation of the site of the Abattis and Kotika Mountain presents, because of its picturesque, legendary and historical character, a general interest within the meaning of Article L. 341-1 of the Environment Code arrested. STOPPED: Article 1: Is inscribed among the sites of the department of Guyana, the group formed by the Abattis and the Kotikasur Mountain on the territory of the Papaichton Commune, of a surface area of about 32 000 hectares”

… 
Downsize in 2012 via Ministerial Decree:
“Considerant que la preservation de l'ensemble forme par les Abattis et la Montagne Cottica, sur le territoire de la commune de Papaichton, presente en raison de ses caracteres historique, scientifique, legendaire et pittoresque, un interet general au sense de l'article L.341-1 du code de l'environnement,  est classe parmi les sites du departemente de la Guyane sur le territoire de la commune de Papaichton, l'ensemble forme par les Abattis et la Montagne cottica de'une superficie de 16000 hectares environ, delimite comme suit, conformemente a la carte au 1/50000 annexee au present arrete en allant dans le sense des aiguilles d'une montre…….est abroge en tant q'il concerne le site classe par le prsent arrete, l'arrete du ministre de l'ecologie et du developpement durable, en date du 19 december 2005portant inscription parmi les sites du departement de la Guyane de l'ensemble forme par les Abattis et la Montagne Kotika sur le territoire de la commune de Papaichton” / “Considering that the preservation of the ensemble formed by the Abattis and the Mountain Cottica, on the territory of the municipality of Papaichton, presents because of its historical, scientific, legendary and picturesque characteristics, a general interest in the sense of the article L .341-1 of the code of the environment, is classified among the sites of the departemente of Guiana on the territory of the commune of Papaichton, the group formed by the Abattis and Cottica Mountain of a surface of about 16000 hectares, delimit as follows, in accordance with the 1: 50000 map appended to this order by going clockwise…..is repealed as regards the site classed by the present order, the order of the Minister of Ecology and Sustainable Development, dated December 19, 2005, bearing the name of the sites of the Department of Guyana of the whole form by Abattis and Kotika Mountain on the territory of the commune of Papaichton”
Sources: Arrêté du 15 décembre 2011  et Arrêté du 19 décembre 2005

primarynam: San Matias San Carlos Protection Forest
allnames: Bosque de Proteccion San Matias San Carlos, San Matias San Carlos Protection Forest
Supporting:
Systemic downgrade of all protected areas in Peru established before 1991. The downgrade was reversed in 1997 for 17 out of 35 of these protected areas; those PAs with protections reversed are IUCN category II and III, while those without protections reversed are all IUCN category VI.

Article 71 of the Environment and Natural Resources Code (Codigo del Medio Ambiente y los Recursos Naturales, established by Decreto Legislativo No 613) of 1990 prohibited the extraction of resources in all protected areas. Article 71 was repealed in 1991 by Decreto Legislativo No 653 (of 08-01-1991); this repeal constitutes a systemic downgrade for all protected area established before 1991 (35 national-level PAs).  This was later \replaced\" by Decreto Ley 655 (Article 12)
Sources: which required Environmental Impact Studies for extractive activities within protected areas; this provision was repealed in 1993 by Ley 26221. These changes (D.L. 655 and Ley 26221) do not constitute reversals
Map_Details: as they did not restore the prohibition of extractive activities within protected areas.  In 1997
Map_Sources: the new Law of Protected Areas (Ley 26834) established the categories of \"uso directo\" (extractive activities allowed) and \"uso indirecto\" (extractive activities prohibited\"). This 1997 Law constitutes a reversal of the 1991 systemic downgrade for the protected areas in the uso indirecto category: National Parks
Date_Add: and Historic Sanctuaries (17 protected areas). The other categories of protected areas are considered uso directo
Last_Update: and the PADDD event of 1991 was not reversed (18 protected areas).

PADDD_ID: Multiple causes is listed as the proximate cause: as the provision was open ended and would allow multiple types of extractive activities (\"energy of non-renewable natural resources\") including oil and gas
ISO3166: suggest that the legal changes were related to oil and gas extraction.

PADDD_ID: Environment and Natural Resources Code of 1990 (Decreto Legislativo No 613):

\"Artículo 71.- LIMITACION AL APROVECHAMIENTO DE RECURSOS NO RENOVABLES. Es prohibido desarrollar actividades para aprovechamiento energético o de recursos naturales no renovables en el ámbito de las áreas naturales protegidas. (*) Artículo derogado por la Primera Disposición Final del Decreto Legislativo Nº 653 publicada el 01-08-91 / Article 71.- LIMITATION ON THE USE OF NON-RENEWABLE RESOURCES. It is forbidden to develop activities for the use of energy or non-renewable natural resources in the area of protected natural areas. (*) Article repealed by the First Final Provision of Legislative Decree No. 653 published on 08-01-91\"

allnames: Reserva Nacional Pacaya Samiria, Pacaya Samiria National Reserve
Supporting:
Systemic downgrade of all protected areas in Peru established before 1991. The downgrade was reversed in 1997 for 17 out of 35 of these protected areas; those PAs with protections reversed are IUCN category II and III, while those without protections reversed are all IUCN category VI.

Article 71 of the Environment and Natural Resources Code (Codigo del Medio Ambiente y los Recursos Naturales, established by Decreto Legislativo No 613) of 1990 prohibited the extraction of resources in all protected areas. Article 71 was repealed in 1991 by Decreto Legislativo No 653 (of 08-01-1991); this repeal constitutes a systemic downgrade for all protected area established before 1991 (35 national-level PAs).  This was later \replaced\" by Decreto Ley 655 (Article 12)
Sources: which required Environmental Impact Studies for extractive activities within protected areas; this provision was repealed in 1993 by Ley 26221. These changes (D.L. 655 and Ley 26221) do not constitute reversals
Map_Details: as they did not restore the prohibition of extractive activities within protected areas.  In 1997
Map_Sources: the new Law of Protected Areas (Ley 26834) established the categories of \"uso directo\" (extractive activities allowed) and \"uso indirecto\" (extractive activities prohibited\"). This 1997 Law constitutes a reversal of the 1991 systemic downgrade for the protected areas in the uso indirecto category: National Parks
Date_Add: and Historic Sanctuaries (17 protected areas). The other categories of protected areas are considered uso directo
Last_Update: and the PADDD event of 1991 was not reversed (18 protected areas).

PADDD_ID: Multiple causes is listed as the proximate cause: as the provision was open ended and would allow multiple types of extractive activities (\"energy of non-renewable natural resources\") including oil and gas
ISO3166: suggest that the legal changes were related to oil and gas extraction.

PADDD_ID: Environment and Natural Resources Code of 1990 (Decreto Legislativo No 613):

\"Artículo 71.- LIMITACION AL APROVECHAMIENTO DE RECURSOS NO RENOVABLES. Es prohibido desarrollar actividades para aprovechamiento energético o de recursos naturales no renovables en el ámbito de las áreas naturales protegidas. (*) Artículo derogado por la Primera Disposición Final del Decreto Legislativo Nº 653 publicada el 01-08-91 / Article 71.- LIMITATION ON THE USE OF NON-RENEWABLE RESOURCES. It is forbidden to develop activities for the use of energy or non-renewable natural resources in the area of protected natural areas. (*) Article repealed by the First Final Provision of Legislative Decree No. 653 published on 08-01-91\"

allnames: Parque Nacional Tingo Maria, Tingo Maria National Park; La Cueva de las Lechuzas National Reserve; Reserva Nacional La Cueva de las Lechuzas
Supporting:
Systemic downgrade of all protected areas in Peru established before 1991. The downgrade was reversed in 1997 for 17 out of 35 of these protected areas; those PAs with protections reversed are IUCN category II and III, while those without protections reversed are all IUCN category VI.

Article 71 of the Environment and Natural Resources Code (Codigo del Medio Ambiente y los Recursos Naturales, established by Decreto Legislativo No 613) of 1990 prohibited the extraction of resources in all protected areas. Article 71 was repealed in 1991 by Decreto Legislativo No 653 (of 08-01-1991); this repeal constitutes a systemic downgrade for all protected area established before 1991 (35 national-level PAs).  This was later \replaced\" by Decreto Ley 655 (Article 12)
Sources: which required Environmental Impact Studies for extractive activities within protected areas; this provision was repealed in 1993 by Ley 26221. These changes (D.L. 655 and Ley 26221) do not constitute reversals
Map_Details: as they did not restore the prohibition of extractive activities within protected areas.  In 1997
Map_Sources: the new Law of Protected Areas (Ley 26834) established the categories of \"uso directo\" (extractive activities allowed) and \"uso indirecto\" (extractive activities prohibited\"). This 1997 Law constitutes a reversal of the 1991 systemic downgrade for the protected areas in the uso indirecto category: National Parks
Date_Add: and Historic Sanctuaries (17 protected areas). The other categories of protected areas are considered uso directo
Last_Update: and the PADDD event of 1991 was not reversed (18 protected areas).

PADDD_ID: Multiple causes is listed as the proximate cause: as the provision was open ended and would allow multiple types of extractive activities (\"energy of non-renewable natural resources\") including oil and gas
ISO3166: suggest that the legal changes were related to oil and gas extraction.

PADDD_ID: Environment and Natural Resources Code of 1990 (Decreto Legislativo No 613):

\"Artículo 71.- LIMITACION AL APROVECHAMIENTO DE RECURSOS NO RENOVABLES. Es prohibido desarrollar actividades para aprovechamiento energético o de recursos naturales no renovables en el ámbito de las áreas naturales protegidas. (*) Artículo derogado por la Primera Disposición Final del Decreto Legislativo Nº 653 publicada el 01-08-91 / Article 71.- LIMITATION ON THE USE OF NON-RENEWABLE RESOURCES. It is forbidden to develop activities for the use of energy or non-renewable natural resources in the area of protected natural areas. (*) Article repealed by the First Final Provision of Legislative Decree No. 653 published on 08-01-91\"

allnames: Sanctuario Nacional Pampas del Heath; Bahuaja Sonene National Park; Parque Nacional Bahuaja Sonene
Supporting:
Systemic downgrade of all protected areas in Peru established before 1991. The downgrade was reversed in 1997 for 17 out of 35 of these protected areas; those PAs with protections reversed are IUCN category II and III, while those without protections reversed are all IUCN category VI.

Article 71 of the Environment and Natural Resources Code (Codigo del Medio Ambiente y los Recursos Naturales, established by Decreto Legislativo No 613) of 1990 prohibited the extraction of resources in all protected areas. Article 71 was repealed in 1991 by Decreto Legislativo No 653 (of 08-01-1991); this repeal constitutes a systemic downgrade for all protected area established before 1991 (35 national-level PAs).  This was later \replaced\" by Decreto Ley 655 (Article 12)
Sources: which required Environmental Impact Studies for extractive activities within protected areas; this provision was repealed in 1993 by Ley 26221. These changes (D.L. 655 and Ley 26221) do not constitute reversals
Map_Details: as they did not restore the prohibition of extractive activities within protected areas.  In 1997
Map_Sources: the new Law of Protected Areas (Ley 26834) established the categories of \"uso directo\" (extractive activities allowed) and \"uso indirecto\" (extractive activities prohibited\"). This 1997 Law constitutes a reversal of the 1991 systemic downgrade for the protected areas in the uso indirecto category: National Parks
Date_Add: and Historic Sanctuaries (17 protected areas). The other categories of protected areas are considered uso directo
Last_Update: and the PADDD event of 1991 was not reversed (18 protected areas).

PADDD_ID: Multiple causes is listed as the proximate cause: as the provision was open ended and would allow multiple types of extractive activities (\"energy of non-renewable natural resources\") including oil and gas
ISO3166: suggest that the legal changes were related to oil and gas extraction.

PADDD_ID: Environment and Natural Resources Code of 1990 (Decreto Legislativo No 613):

\"Artículo 71.- LIMITACION AL APROVECHAMIENTO DE RECURSOS NO RENOVABLES. Es prohibido desarrollar actividades para aprovechamiento energético o de recursos naturales no renovables en el ámbito de las áreas naturales protegidas. (*) Artículo derogado por la Primera Disposición Final del Decreto Legislativo Nº 653 publicada el 01-08-91 / Article 71.- LIMITATION ON THE USE OF NON-RENEWABLE RESOURCES. It is forbidden to develop activities for the use of energy or non-renewable natural resources in the area of protected natural areas. (*) Article repealed by the First Final Provision of Legislative Decree No. 653 published on 08-01-91\"

allnames: Bosque Nacional Biabo Cordillera Azul; Cordillera Azul National Park
Supporting:
Biabo Cordillera Azul National Forest was established in 1963 by R.S. 442-63-AG (October 9, 1963) with an extension of 20845 sq-km. As part of D.S. No 11-96-AG in 1996, all National Forests were excluded from the protected area system:

\Articulo 6: Excluyase del Sistema Nacional de Areas Naturales Protegidas por el Estado (SINANPE) a los Bosques Nacionales por estar destinados a la produccion permanente de madera
Sources: otros productos forestales
Map_Sources: conforme a lo establecido en el Articulo 10 de la Ley Forestal y de Fauna Silvestre
Notes: dada por Decreto Ley No 21147. / Article 6: Excludes from the National System of Natural Areas Protected by the State (SINANPE) to the National Forests for being destined to the permanent production of wood
AddedBy: according to the established in Article 10 of the Forest and Wildlife Law
isLatestVe: given by Decree Law No. 21147.\" Source: Decreto Supremo No 011-96-AG

GeoDataTyp: National Forests were degazetted en masse by government decree to enable commercial logging (Peru Ministry of Agriculture 1996).  Subsequently
Region: a portion of these areas were regazetted into new types of protected areas.\" (Forrest et al. 2015).

PADDD_ID: \"National Forests are no longer a PA category. They are subject to commercial logging\"; Since 1996 National Forests (used for timber production) are no longer included in the Peruvian Protected Area System (Sistema Nacional de areas Protegidas- SINANPE). - Personal communication

The land that was once Biabo Cordillera Azul National Forest was later incorporated into the Biabo Cordillera Reserved Zone and Permanent Protection Forest Biabo Cordillera Azul in 2000 (Decreto Supremo 050-2000). In 2011
GeoDataTyp: the Biabo Cordillera Reserved Zone was  incorporated into Cordillera Azul National Park with an extension of 13531.9085 sq-km (Decreto Supremo No 031-2001-AG
Region: 2001).  A portion (9836 sq-km) of the original area of the Biabo Cordillera Azul National Forest was re-protected (reversed) and is now protected a part of the Cordillera Azul National Park.

PADDD_ID: Biabo Cordillera Azul National Forest may also have been downsized (year unknown)
GeoDataTyp: but legal document could not be identified. A document scanned from the Universidad Andina La Molina on Bosques Nacionales states that BCA was downsized by 15.99125 km2 to give the land to the populations Fdo. Belaunde and Nuevo San Martin. "
Region:

In 2011, the Biabo Cordillera Reserved Zone was  incorporated into Cordillera Azul National Park with an extension of 13531.9085 sq-km (Decreto Supremo No 031-2001-AG, 2001).  Overall, 9593 km1 of the original area of the Biabo Cordillera Azul National Forest was re-protected (reversed) and is now protected a part of the Cordillera Azul National Park (as calculated in GIS using the Projected Coordinate System South America Equal Area Conic) as presented in SERNANP (2017).

allnames: Parque Nacional Cutervo, Cutervo National Park; San Andres National Park
Supporting:
Systemic downgrade of all protected areas in Peru established before 1991. The downgrade was reversed in 1997 for 17 out of 35 of these protected areas; those PAs with protections reversed are IUCN category II and III, while those without protections reversed are all IUCN category VI.

Article 71 of the Environment and Natural Resources Code (Codigo del Medio Ambiente y los Recursos Naturales, established by Decreto Legislativo No 613) of 1990 prohibited the extraction of resources in all protected areas. Article 71 was repealed in 1991 by Decreto Legislativo No 653 (of 08-01-1991); this repeal constitutes a systemic downgrade for all protected area established before 1991 (35 national-level PAs).  This was later \replaced\" by Decreto Ley 655 (Article 12)
Sources: which required Environmental Impact Studies for extractive activities within protected areas; this provision was repealed in 1993 by Ley 26221. These changes (D.L. 655 and Ley 26221) do not constitute reversals
Map_Details: as they did not restore the prohibition of extractive activities within protected areas.  In 1997
Map_Sources: the new Law of Protected Areas (Ley 26834) established the categories of \"uso directo\" (extractive activities allowed) and \"uso indirecto\" (extractive activities prohibited\"). This 1997 Law constitutes a reversal of the 1991 systemic downgrade for the protected areas in the uso indirecto category: National Parks
Date_Add: and Historic Sanctuaries (17 protected areas). The other categories of protected areas are considered uso directo
Last_Update: and the PADDD event of 1991 was not reversed (18 protected areas).

\"Artículo 71.- LIMITACION AL APROVECHAMIENTO DE RECURSOS NO RENOVABLES. Es prohibido desarrollar actividades para aprovechamiento energético o de recursos naturales no renovables en el ámbito de las áreas naturales protegidas. (*) Artículo derogado por la Primera Disposición Final del Decreto Legislativo Nº 653 publicada el 01-08-91 / Article 71.- LIMITATION ON THE USE OF NON-RENEWABLE RESOURCES. It is forbidden to develop activities for the use of energy or non-renewable natural resources in the area of protected natural areas. (*) Article repealed by the First Final Provision of Legislative Decree No. 653 published on 08-01-91\"

allnames: Bosque Nacional Pastaza-Morona-Marañón, Morona-Pastaza-Marañón National Forest, Bosque Nacional Morona-Pastaza-Marañón
Supporting:
The Pastaza-Morona-Marañón National Forest was established in 1963 (R.S. 442-33-AG) with an extension of 3750 sq-km. It was degazetted in 1996 when National Forests were excluded from the National Protected Area System: 

\Articulo 6: Excluyase del Sistema Nacional de Areas Naturales Protegidas por el Estado (SINANPE) a los Bosques Nacionales por estar destinados a la produccion permanente de madera
Sources: otros productos forestales
Map_Sources: conforme a lo establecido en el Articulo 10 de la Ley Forestal y de Fauna Silvestre
Notes: dada por Decreto Ley No 21147. / Article 6: Excludes from the National System of Natural Areas Protected by the State (SINANPE) to the National Forests for being destined to the permanent production of wood
AddedBy: according to the established in Article 10 of the Forest and Wildlife Law
isLatestVe: given by Decree Law No. 21147.\" Source: Decreto Supremo No 011-96-AG

GeoDataTyp: National Forests were degazetted en masse by government decree to enable commercial logging (Peru Ministry of Agriculture 1996).  Subsequently
Region: a portion of these areas were regazetted into new types of protected areas.\" (Forrest et al. 2015).

allnames: Bosque Nacional Alexander von Humboldt
Supporting:
The Alexander von Humboldt National Forest was established by R.S. no 266 10-06-1965 with an extension of 5374.38 sq-km. It was then amplified by R.S. No 0462-74-AG 05-06-1974 to an extension of 6450.00 sq-km. It was later downsized in 1989 by D.S. 055-89-AG of 02-09-1989, to an extension of 4097.4465 sq-km. In 1996, D.S. No 011-96-AG re-structured the system of protected areas; National Forests were no longer considered as protected areas. 

\Articulo 6: Excluyase del Sistema Nacional de Areas Naturales Protegidas por el Estado (SINANPE) a los Bosques Nacionales por estar destinados a la produccion permanente de madera
Sources: otros productos forestales

AddedBy: according to the established in Article 10 of the Forest and Wildlife Law
isLatestVe: given by Decree Law No. 21147.\" Source: Decreto Supremo No 011-96-AG

allnames: Bosque de Proteccion Pui Pui, Pui Pui Protection Forest
Supporting:
Systemic downgrade of all protected areas in Peru established before 1991. The downgrade was reversed in 1997 for 17 out of 35 of these protected areas; those PAs with protections reversed are IUCN category II and III, while those without protections reversed are all IUCN category VI.

Article 71 of the Environment and Natural Resources Code (Codigo del Medio Ambiente y los Recursos Naturales, established by Decreto Legislativo No 613) of 1990 prohibited the extraction of resources in all protected areas. Article 71 was repealed in 1991 by Decreto Legislativo No 653 (of 08-01-1991); this repeal constitutes a systemic downgrade for all protected area established before 1991 (35 national-level PAs).  This was later \replaced\" by Decreto Ley 655 (Article 12)
Sources: which required Environmental Impact Studies for extractive activities within protected areas; this provision was repealed in 1993 by Ley 26221. These changes (D.L. 655 and Ley 26221) do not constitute reversals
Map_Details: as they did not restore the prohibition of extractive activities within protected areas.  In 1997
Map_Sources: the new Law of Protected Areas (Ley 26834) established the categories of \"uso directo\" (extractive activities allowed) and \"uso indirecto\" (extractive activities prohibited\"). This 1997 Law constitutes a reversal of the 1991 systemic downgrade for the protected areas in the uso indirecto category: National Parks
Date_Add: and Historic Sanctuaries (17 protected areas). The other categories of protected areas are considered uso directo
Last_Update: and the PADDD event of 1991 was not reversed (18 protected areas).

PADDD_ID: Multiple causes is listed as the proximate cause: as the provision was open ended and would allow multiple types of extractive activities (\"energy of non-renewable natural resources\") including oil and gas
ISO3166: suggest that the legal changes were related to oil and gas extraction.

PADDD_ID: Environment and Natural Resources Code of 1990 (Decreto Legislativo No 613):

\"Artículo 71.- LIMITACION AL APROVECHAMIENTO DE RECURSOS NO RENOVABLES. Es prohibido desarrollar actividades para aprovechamiento energético o de recursos naturales no renovables en el ámbito de las áreas naturales protegidas. (*) Artículo derogado por la Primera Disposición Final del Decreto Legislativo Nº 653 publicada el 01-08-91 / Article 71.- LIMITATION ON THE USE OF NON-RENEWABLE RESOURCES. It is forbidden to develop activities for the use of energy or non-renewable natural resources in the area of protected natural areas. (*) Article repealed by the First Final Provision of Legislative Decree No. 653 published on 08-01-91\"

primarynam: Pu'uhonua o Honaunau National Historical Park
allnames: Pu'uhonua o Honaunau National Historical Park
Supporting: \The National Park Service is establishing a management framework to allow the gathering and removal of plants or plant parts by enrolled members of federally recognized Indian tribes for traditional purposes. The rule authorizes agreements between the National Park Service and federally recognized tribes that will facilitate the continuation of tribal cultural practices on lands within areas of the National Park System where those practices traditionally occurred
Sources: without causing a significant adverse impact to park resources or values. This rule respects those tribal cultural practices
Map_Details: furthers the government-to-government relationship between the United States and the tribes
Map_Sources: and provides system-wide consistency for this aspect of National Park Service-tribal relations.\""

allnames: Parque Nacional Chorro El Indio - Doctor Amenodoro Rangel Lamus
Supporting:
Chorro El Indio national park was designated in 1989 (Venezuela 1990a). A second decree (number 861) expanded the park in 1990 (Venezuela 1990b). A third decree (number 2349) did another expansion in 1992 (Venezuela 1992). This last Decree 2349 was annuled by the Supreme Court according to it ruling of October 7th 2003 (Venezuela 2004). This was the consequence of a claim set by a group of land owners who argued that the second expansion was not supported by a technical study. The Supreme Court ruled its decision because the Environment Ministry failed to provide a proof  of the existence of such a technical study. As a consequence the boundaries of the park remained as established by the second decree, number 861 (Venezuela 1990b).

“En fecha 9 de marzo de 1995, se recibió … expediente contentivo del recurso contencioso  administrativo de nulidad interpuesto … por los abogados … apoderados judiciales de los ciudadanos … contra el acto administrativo contenido en el Decreto Nº 2.349 del 5 de junio de 1992, por medio del cual se establece la AMPLIACIÓN DEL PARQUE NACIONAL CHORRO EL INDIO…”. …“En consecuencia de lo anterior, y al no haberse efectuado el informe técnico que determinara las razones por las cuales existían méritos suficientes para ampliar el Parque Nacional…”…“este Tribunal Supremo de Justicia en Sala Político-Administrativa, administrando justicia en nombre de la República y por autoridad de la Ley, declara CON LUGAR el recurso contencioso administrativo de nulidad…”…“…en consecuencia, queda ANULADO el acto administrativo contenido en el Decreto Nº 2.349 del 5 de junio de 1992, por medio del cual se establece la AMPLIACIÓN DEL PARQUE NACIONAL CHORRO EL INDIO…” (Venezuela 2004) /
